channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2015 The New York Times Company

item.title: Chinese Anticorruption Agency Investigates a Security Official
item.description: China’s investigation of Vice Minister Ma Jian was the latest demonstration of President Xi Jinping’s drive to consolidate control of the levers of Communist Party power.
item.category: Ministry of State Security of the People's Republic of China
Central Commission for Discipline Inspection (Communist Party of China)
item.dc:creator: By CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: Obama and Senator Robert Menendez Spar on How to Handle Iran
item.description: President Obama and Mr. Menendez traded sharp words on Thursday over whether Congress should impose new sanctions on Iran, according to two people who witnessed the exchange.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL D. SHEAR
item.media:description: Senator Robert Menendez said that new sanctions would need to be imposed on Iran.

item.title: World Briefing: Russia: Opposition Protesters Are Arrested After Clash
item.description: Opposition protesters were arrested in Moscow on Thursday evening after scuffles broke out between supporters of President Vladimir V. Putin and Aleksei A. Navalny.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW ROTH

item.title: F.B.I. Chief Criticizes Times on Qaeda Source
item.description: The F.B.I. director sharply criticized The Times on Thursday for anonymously quoting a member of a terrorist group in an article about the deadly attacks last week in France.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL S. SCHMIDT

item.title: Netanya Journal: For Jews From France, a Sociable Landing Spot in Israel
item.description: With safety issues growing after the terrorist attacks in Paris, the French economy struggling and an open invitation from Israel to relocate, French-Israeli Jews in Netanya await new arrivals.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER
item.media:credit: Rina Castelnuovo for The New York Times
item.media:description: Suzanne Guez, who splits time living in Paris and Netanya, Israel, said her children did not want her to return to Paris.

item.title: U.N. Says Meeting Is Set on Middle East
item.description: The United States, the European Union, Russia and the United Nations will convene to seek a resumption of Israeli-Palestinian peace negotiations.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: French Rein In Speech Backing Acts of Terror
item.description: Recent court cases in Paris have raised accusations of a double standard on free speech with some pointing to a divide between cartoonists and statements made by Muslim supporters of the gunmen.
item.dc:creator: By DOREEN CARVAJAL and ALAN COWELL
item.media:description: The funeral in Montreuil for Bernard Verlhac, a cartoonist who died in the attack on Charlie Hebdo.

item.title: Starting Friday, U.S. Will Ease Restrictions on Travel to Cuba
item.description: While ordinary tourism remains banned by law, new rules put in place by President Obama will make it easier for Americans to visit Cuba than it has been for most of the last 50 years.
item.dc:creator: By PETER BAKER and RANDAL C. ARCHIBOLD

item.title: French Rein In Speech Backing Acts of Terror
item.description: In separate speeches, President François Hollande and Chancellor Angela Merkel struck similar tones in urging tolerance and inclusiveness.
item.dc:creator: By DOREEN CARVAJAL and ALAN COWELL

item.title: World Briefing: Colombia: President Hints at Shift on a Cease-Fire
item.description: President Juan Manuel Santos appeared to open a window this week to a bilateral cease-fire with the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia.
item.dc:creator: By WILLIAM NEUMAN

item.title: 2 Suspects Killed in Gun Battle in Belgian Antiterror Raid
item.description: The raid in eastern Belgium also left a third person gravely injured, as the authorities stepped up their efforts against extremists.
item.dc:creator: By JAMES KANTER
item.media:description: Police officers in Verviers, Belgium, at the scene of an antiterrorism operation on Thursday.

item.title: World Briefing: Mauritania: Slavery Foes Get Two-Year Sentences
item.description: A candidate in last year’s presidential election in Mauritania was jailed for two years on Thursday along with two other people who had organized a march against slavery, their defense lawyer said.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing: Saudi Arabia: U.N. Denounces Flogging of Blogger
item.description: The United Nations high commissioner for human rights, Prince Zeid Ra’ad Zeid al-Hussein of Jordan, publicly appealed to Saudi Arabia on Thursday to halt the flogging of a blogger.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Ship-Supply Contractor and Navy Captain Plead Guilty in Scandal
item.description: A fourth Navy official pleaded guilty on bribery charges for accepting free trips, meals and prostitutes from a contractor.
item.dc:creator: By CHRISTOPHER DREW and DANIELLE IVORY
item.media:description: Leonard Glenn Francis, a Malaysian contractor who has been accused of overbilling the Navy by more than $20 million.

item.title: U.S. to Help Bulgaria Depend Less on Russians
item.description: Secretary of State John Kerry said Thursday that the United States would help Bulgaria reduce its dependence on Russia, which supplies 85 percent of its gas and all of its nuclear fuel.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON

item.title: In China’s Antigraft Campaign, Small Victories and Bigger Doubts
item.description: Two years into a far-reaching government campaign against official corruption, many ordinary Chinese remain deeply cynical about whether it can succeed.
item.category: Central Commission for Discipline Inspection (Communist Party of China)
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW JACOBS
item.media:description: Yang Tianrong, 75, a resident of Beidaihe believes the government’s efforts to evict villagers from their homes is part of a corrupt real estate project.

item.title: Bodies of French Gunmen Lie Unburied, and, It Appears, Mostly Unwanted
item.description: The burial of the three raises a difficult question for France, which in the past has offered a Muslim burial even to those who committed terrorist acts.
item.dc:creator: By MAÏA de la BAUME and DAN BILEFSKY

item.title: Target Ends Its Unprofitable Gamble in Canada
item.description: The company, which has made major management changes in the last year, is closing more than 100 Canadian stores less than two years after they opened.
item.dc:creator: By IAN AUSTEN and HIROKO TABUCHI
item.media:credit: Clockwise from top left: Peter Power/Reuters; Nathan Denette, via The Canadian Press; Peter Power, via Reuters; Dan Riedlhuber, via Reuters; Dave Chidley, via The Canadian Press; Andrew Vaughan, via The Canadian Press; Fred Thornhill, via Reuters; Lindsay Mackenzie for The New York Times; Ryan Remiorz, via The Canadian Press; Ben Nelms, via Reuters; Ben Nelms, via Reuters; Rene Johnston, via Toronto Star, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Less than two years after opening in Canada, Target said on Thursday that it would close its 133 stores in the country, laying off 17,600 people.

item.title: Two Italian Aid Workers Held Hostage in Syria Are Released
item.description: The women, who had been working in the northern city of Aleppo, were reported seized in August. It was not immediately clear why they were freed.
item.dc:creator: By GAIA PIANIGIANI and RICK GLADSTONE
item.media:credit: Islamic Sham, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Greta Ramelli, left, and Vanessa Marzullo in a video apparently produced by their captors had said their lives were in danger.

item.title: U.N. to Renew Syria Talks, Seeking Aleppo Cease-Fire
item.description: The United Nations hopes to negotiate a cease-fire around the northern city and restart a process “with a clear political horizon.” But diplomats see little sign of a breakthrough.
item.dc:creator: By NICK CUMMING-BRUCE
